channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: 3 Americans Are Killed by Guard at Afghan Hospital
item.description: The attack took place at a hospital in Kabul that specializes in the treatment of disabled children and women’s health issues, official said. The gunman had recently been assigned there.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI

item.title: India Ink: The Autumn of a Patriarch
item.description: As Muthuvel Karunanidhi, the chief of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam in Tamil Nadu, plots a resurgence in the 2014 elections, there is the feeling that this may prove to be a comeback too far for the grand old man of Indian politics.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS

item.title: As Wine Fetches Staggering Sums, Fakery Claims Rise
item.description: Connoisseurs driving up the prices of rare and collectible wines have spurred a wave of counterfeiters who target collectors eager to flaunt their trophies.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Stephen Williams, head of the Antique Wine Company of London, which is being sued by an Atlanta collector for $25 million.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Plan to Sell Condoms in Schools Encounters Resistance
item.description: Middle schools in Xi’an in Shaanxi Province should sell condoms, education officials have said. Family planning officials say they know the move is controversial, but hope it will help stop the spread of H.I.V.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Some teachers object that selling condoms in middle and high schools will only encourage promiscuity.

item.title: India Ink: Memories of Religious Riots Overshadow Vote in Bihar
item.description: In the district of Bhagalpur, Muslim voters weighed a choice between two political camps to counter the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Mallika Begum, a survivor of the riots in Bhagalpur, Bihar.

item.title: Israel Halts Talks, Citing Palestinian Unity Agreement
item.description: The Israeli government said that it would not under any circumstances negotiate with a Palestinian government that was backed by Hamas, the militant Islamic group.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: As Ukraine Clashes With Pro-Russia Militias, Moscow Announces Military Drills
item.description: Russia’s move was certain to raise tensions with the United States and its allies, who have demanded that Russia stop stirring unrest in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A member of the Ukrainian special forces took position in the eastern city of Slovyansk on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: India’s Weather Agency Forecasts Weaker Monsoon
item.description: India’s meteorological department predicted that rainfall would be below average this monsoon season, which could have wider effects on the economy.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: A boy running across a flooded street in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on June 9, 2013.

item.title: India Ink: Tamil Nadu Warms Up to Modi and His Party
item.description: The Bharatiya Janata Party is hoping that a growing urban population, voter disaffection with incumbents and Mr. Modi’s charisma will help it make some headway in a state that it has found impossible to crack in the past.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, right, the prime ministerial candidate of the Bharatiya Janata Party, with Rajinikanth, a popular film actor, in Chennai, capital of the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, earlier this month.

item.title: 3 Americans Are Killed by Guard at Afghan Hospital
item.description: The attack took place at a hospital in Kabul that specializes in the treatment of disabled children and women’s health issues, official said. The gunman had recently been assigned there.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI
item.media:description: Afghan security officials outside of Cure International Hospital in Kabul on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bieber Apology Over Shrine Visit Falls Flat in China
item.description: Despite efforts by the pop star Justin Bieber to make amends after his visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, Chinese online commenters seemed skeptical about his sincerity.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Letter From Africa: At Pistorius Trial, Twitterati Have Their Day in Court
item.description: In the avalanche of 140-character snippets and instant assessments, are the tweeters giving away their stock in trade — the news — for free?
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius held his ears as he sat in the dock during his trial in Pretoria on April 17th.

item.title: Court Releases Japanese Ship Impounded by China
item.description: The seizure of the ship raised the prospect of China seeking compensation for claims stemming from its conflict with Japan before and during World War II.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Obama Says Pact Obliges U.S. to Protect Japan in Islands Fight
item.description: While offering security assurances to Japan, President Obama did not take sides over who has sovereignty over islands that are also claimed by China.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Britain Moves to Prevent Young People From Joining Syrian War
item.description: The campaign reflects growing concern in Europe that jihadists returning home from the conflict represent a “great danger.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Lens: Following the Global Armenian Diaspora
item.description: Scout Tufankjian has been traveling the world photographing Armenian communities large and small, where traditions endure amid diversity.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Armenian men hanging out outside a small recreation center in Sanjak Camp in Bourj Hammoud, Lebanon. The camp, which was built to house refugees from the Armenian genocide and is one of the last remaining inhabited Armenian refugee camps in the world, is being demolished to make way for new development. June 28, 2013.

item.title: India Ink: Mumbai’s Slum Dwellers Wary of Recycled Promises
item.description: Every election year, parties pledge to help redevelop the sprawling slums in the city, but the residents in these densely packed neighborhoods see little progress.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: A view of Ambedkar Nagar, a slum in south Mumbai.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tainted Food in China Cited in Cyclist’s Failed Doping Test
item.description: The cyclist Michael Rogers tested positive for clenbuterol, which is used by farmers in China to produce leaner meat.
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report Finds Widespread Water Pollution in China
item.description: The majority of areas being monitored for water pollution by the Chinese government had “very poor” or “relatively poor” underground water quality.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sacks of carbon pellets are used to absorb water pollutants from a chemical spill into a stream in Hubei Province.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 23
item.description: Arvind Kejriwal, chief of the Aam Aadmi Party, filed his nomination to contest a seat from the temple town of Varanasi in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, center, leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, addressing supporters before filing his nomination Wednesday to contest a seat from Varanasi, in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. Mr. Kejriwal will be squaring off against Narendra Modi, prime ministerial candidate of the main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.

item.title: India Ink: What Female Voters Say About Women’s Safety in Mumbai
item.description: Women from all walks of life talk about how secure they feel in India’s financial capital.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Shabina Sheikh wishes her young daughter could roam around Mumbai without worry.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Backlash Over Hong Kong’s Treatment of Mainland Visitors
item.description: A video of a confrontation on a Hong Kong street is raising questions of whether the harsh treatment of mainland visitors has gone too far.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Turkey Offers Condolences to Armenians Over Killings
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s office posted a web statement, but the government stood by its position that the killings of at least 1.5 million Armenians in 1915 were not a genocide.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 24
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A group of people in Mumbai, capital of the western state of Maharashtra, got their faces painted on Wednesday to encourage voting in the sixth phase of India's general elections.

item.title: Anti-Corruption Group Finds Fault With European Union
item.description: A report by Transparency International, calling for a more open approach to policy making, might provide fuel for the union’s critics.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The European Parliament in Brussels. A new report is outlining shortcomings in the governance of European Union institutions.
